howItWorks.title: How Diaphragmatic Breathing Works
howItWorks.description1: Controlled breathing through the 4:6 pattern which emphasizes a longer exhalation stimulates the vagus nerve, a primary component of the parasympathetic nervous system. Activating this nerve sends signals that help transition the body from a "fight or flight" state to a "rest and repair" mode.
howItWorks.description2: This shift has several measurable physiological benefits. It can lead to a lower heart rate and reduced blood pressure. The relaxation of blood vessels allows for improved circulation, increasing oxygen flow to the brain. Furthermore, this calming response positively influences digestion and supports the body's immune system.
howItWorks.description3: Consciously practicing 4:6 breathing technique is an effective way to manage stress and promote overall well-being.

vagalActivation.title: Vagal Nerve Activation
vagalActivation.description: Slow, deep breathing stimulates the vagus nerve, which connects your brain to your heart and digestive system, promoting a calm state.

gasExchange.title: Optimal Gas Exchange
gasExchange.description: Breathing at 4-6 breaths per minute optimizes oxygen delivery and CO2 balance, reducing the hyperventilation that often accompanies anxiety.

stressHormones.title: Stress Hormone Reduction
stressHormones.description: Regular practice decreases cortisol and other stress hormones, creating lasting improvements in your body's baseline stress response.

science.title: The Science Behind Breathing Exercise
science.description: Research consistently demonstrates that diaphragmatic breathing produces measurable reductions in anxiety, stress hormones, and physiological arousal. An 8-week program with 20 sessions of 15-minute diaphragmatic breathing lowered negative affect by 2.55 points and decreased cortisol levels by 1.32-1.66 ng/mL in healthy adults.

anxietyReduction.title: Anxiety Reduction
anxietyReduction.description: In COVID-19 patients, 5 days of guided deep breathing (15-20 minutes, 4x daily) reduced anxiety scores on DASS-21 from 14.86 to 8.44—a 43% improvement—while controls showed no change.

panicDisorders.title: Panic Disorder Treatment
panicDisorders.description: A review of 16 studies found slow breathing at 8-10 breaths per minute over 2-12 months reduced panic attack frequency and normalized CO2 levels in patients with panic disorder and agoraphobia.

gadImprovement.title: Generalized Anxiety Improvement
gadImprovement.description: In 41 GAD patients, 3 months of daily breathing practice (15-20 min, 4+ days/week) reduced anxiety scores from 40.90 to 13.24 on the BAI—a 68% improvement.

posture.title: Posture
posture.description: Sit or stand straight to allow full lung expansion. Shoulders relaxed, not hunched.

environment.title: Environment
environment.description: Find a quiet space where you won't be interrupted. Comfortable temperature helps focus.

consistency.title: Consistency
consistency.description: Practice the same technique for a week before switching. Building familiarity improves effectiveness.
